title: Backing data silo attack: Alfresco sharding, SOLR for non-flat objects
targetAudience: Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
Building a single content platform for few dozens quite loaded applications is a complex task. It becomes even worse, if application developers are not sure about expected load and content structure in the next few years. This talk concentrates on two aspects of this challenge.

* Clustering and sharding - different solutions for different problems. Sharding Alfresco - reasons and implementation. Building federation proxy to aggregate multiple independent Alfresco repositories and provide a single API entry point on top of them. Live technical experience only - issues, solutions, limitations, lessons learned. Live benchmark data included.

* Handling complex search queries on top of sharded installation. A lot of search use cases are not covered with out of the box flat SOLR indexing. Sometimes users need to search complex nested objects, not just files. (It's more or less about indexing associations - 'I'd like to find all cases (node A), created by the company (node B) with name matching this, and containing child documents (nodes C) registered not later than that date' - it's quite hard to match this query having only nodes properties in the index.) We implemented an external SOLR Cloud integrated with sharded Alfresco installation to serve such complex search requests using custom indexing logic based on SOLR nested objects. In this talk we will cover reasons for such custom indexing architecture, and share an experience of its implementation.

Bonuses:
* Short live demo - Share UI on top of sharded Alfresco
* Call for community participation - let's turn this experience into open source project

title: 2 years of Aikau - how is it faring and what do we want from it?
targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
After a time of development without a public name, the Aikau framework was introduced to the Alfresco community in Feburary of 2014. Since then there have been two product releases of the Alfresco ECM product and more than 70 incremental releases of the Aikau framework. In addition to new features of the core product, various official and community addons now use the framework to enhance or customize the Share application.
This talk aims to give an external point-of-view on how the Aikau framework helps users tackle their business requirements in developing both basic customisations to existing functionality and complex, custom business applications. It will look at a sub-set of use cases that are supported by or that members of the community have implemented on top of Aikau, and review the advantages and potential short-comings of the framework in that context. Additionally, the talk will try to summarize community concerns and expectations regarding the future of Aikau, and how the community can work together to make those expectations a reality.

title: PostgreSQL: what you should know to improve your Alfresco
targetAudience: System Administrators, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
The default installation of Alfresco includes a basic installation of PostgreSQL, which already works well for several scenarios. But you can do much better with PostgreSQL, improving the performance of Alfresco, and making things easier to maintain.

In this presentation you will see how to design a robust solution for a highly-available database; how to take your backups and do auditing analysis without impacting production performance; how to recover Alfresco's database just before the point of a critical user mistake, instead of back to your nightly snapshot.

If you feel (or someone told you) that PostgreSQL is hard to administrate, we will show you why PostgreSQL is actually DBA-friendly. It has excellent documentation and a great community ready to help. In this presentation you will understand how this forever free database will help you to improve your Alfresco.

I believe Alfresco can benefit a lot from PostgreSQL by going beyond a default installation; so I will present topics such as Point-In-Time Recovery, High Availability/Replication, simple database management and performance optimisation.

My profile suits this topic in view of my experience as a speaker in several PostgreSQL conferences, in Europa and USA, with talks that covered general overviews as well as specific topics.

I always enjoy to take questions from the audience and discuss specific points in more detail, either during the talk or after.

title: Multiple Share-based applications on the same back-end Alfresco repository: pitfalls and best practices
targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
Organizations often wish to use Alfresco as the back-end repository for a number of diverse business applications. However straightforward this requirement, the technical implementation is often a challenge since these applications all require specific front-end customisations. When deploying multiple customized Share front-end for these business applications, some aspects such as workflows, dashboards, etc. cannot be easily separated.

One option is building your front-end applications from scratch, but that ignores the wealth of functionality that is available in Share out-of-the-box. Moreover some organizations already use Share as a front-end and would like to keep a consistent experience for their users.

In this talk we share our experience on using multiple customized Share instances as business application front-end on the same Alfresco repository. Some potential pitfalls when developing such solutions are:

* The use of specific personal dashboards for each application, which conflicts with the current single dashboard configuration within Alfresco

* The definition of application-specific workflows, which conflicts with Share’s default behavior of showing all defined workflows

* Out-of-the-box dashlets whose queries are not limited to your application scope.

* …

This talk will give an overview of some of the more dangerous pitfalls we encountered, how we solved them and what best practices to keep in mind.

title: Externalizing permissions in Drools
targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers
abstract: The automation of setting permissions is probably one of the most common extension of Alfresco. To achieve this, Alfresco provides extension points such behaviors coupled with the permission service which allows already many possibilities. However, this logic can be really complex especially when the permissions are set at documents-level. Permissions might depend on meta-data, on external data, can be temporary, even the logic itself could change frequently. Also, in an enterprise environment Alfresco is probably not the only application developed. You might already have business rules in place about permissions that you want to reuse. In a project at CERN, we decided to externalize all this logic in a Business Rules Engine, and then to interface it with Alfresco.

title: Alfresco SDK - Past, Present and The Future
targetAudience: Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
The Alfresco SDK have had a rough life, starting out as a community contribution, finally being picked up by Alfresco and treated as part of the product.

With that being said, the Alfresco SDK has not always been easy to work with. Upgrades have been difficult and it can be tricky to understand and get the most out of the setup.

In this session you will hear about where we are today, how we got there and finally how we can learn from history to create a brand new SDK that will empower all Alfresco developers.

Since discovering Linux in college, he has been enamored with open source products and business models. This brought him to Alfresco where he has enjoyed his work as a solutions engineer, community marketer, developer evangelist, and as head of community relations. Before Alfresco, Richard worked as a developer and system administrator at a variety of small companies and startups.

title: Contributing to Alfresco
targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers
abstract:
The Alfresco product development team recognizes that we need to improve at collaborating with our open source community and accepting contributions. This session continues our conversation on this topic by hosting a panel discussion with various members of the Alfresco product development team and leaders in the open source community.

The session will be moderated by Richard Esplin from Alfresco Product Management, and Boriss Mejias from the Order of the Bee. Topics will include a report from Alfresco Software on changes they have made to make it easier to contribute, the current contribution process, obstacles to contribution, and a discussion on how the contribution process can be further improved.

speakers.name: Boriss
speakers.summary: Co-founder and active member of the Order of the Bee. I've been involved with the Alfresco community and the Alfresco software since 2011. My work at CIRB-CIBG involves the administration of several Alfresco instances, being responsible for their correct operation. Hence, I have to be ready for the coming of the failure. To reduce the stress, I regularly test backups and the recovery process. And this is what I want to share with the attendees.

title: Alfresco Koans
targetAudience: Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
The koans tutorial style has been around for a few years; we decided it would make a good opportunity for our seasoned & certified Alfresco architects and senior developers to create additional hands-on learning material for new starters.
This session introduces the test-driven path to Alfresco enlightment and the principles behind it.

speakers.name: Robin
speakers.summary:
Robin Bramley is the Chief Scientific Officer at Ixxus, a global Alfresco Platinum Partner.

He took Alfresco 0.6 to bits in 2005 and has been using/extending/implementing/integrating/scaling it ever since. Whilst Technical Manager at the first UK Alfresco Gold partner, he built the original IMAP interface to Alfresco. Robin has architected many distributed systems over the past 18 years ranging from a Swaps Trading Platform to Insurance Contract Management and a global Alfresco-based DAM system.

Robin has presented at various international conferences and London meetups; his blog is syndicated by DZone and he has written a series of articles for GroovyMag, including one on CMIS integration with Alfresco that NASA wanted the source code for.

title: Welcome to the jungle - Tips for Alfresco on Amazon Web Services
targetAudience: Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
Many people are familiar with spinning up a small Alfresco instance on a virtual machine, but taking a large-scale, content-centric organisation to the cloud is in a different league altogether.

During this session you can learn lessons from a major programme of work that had to overcome significant technical hurdles, some of which have resulted in changes to Alfresco modules. You will find out how best to:

* migrate terabytes of content from on-prem to the cloud
* adhere to security compliance with encryption at rest.

title: The Alfresco Product Roadmap
targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract: The Alfresco open source community has been key to the fast growth and broad adoption of Alfresco. The Alfresco product team wants to share with the BeeCon attendees some of our key initiatives to evolve and improve the product, so that this audience of open source contributors can understand our product goals and roadmap to achieve them.

speakers.name: Thomas
speakers.summary:
Thomas DeMeo is Vice President of Product Management and General Manager of the Alfresco One product line.

With a mix of early start-up and global corporate experience, Thomas has focused his 25-year career in product roles with Silicon Valley icons including Adobe, HP and Citrix. With deep leadership and product management experience, he has contributed and led teams responsible for industry-leading product lines that each generated over $1B annually. Most recently Thomas served as Senior Director of Product Management at Citrix and focused on helping enterprises deliver apps and data across private, public and hybrid cloud infrastructure. While at HP, Thomas focused on integrated commerce and accessing apps and data across PC and mobile devices. Thomas spent 7 years at Adobe and led the Creative Suite product teams responsible for product integration, file and metadata management and delivered key interfaces into a range of content management systems, like Alfresco.

Thomas earned an MBA from San Jose State University and has an engineering undergraduate degree from Wentworth Institute of Technology in Boston, Massachusetts.

title: Busines Activity Monitoring, a sample use case
targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
Business activity monitoring (BAM) describes the processes and technologies that enhance situation awareness and enable analysis of critical business performance indicators based on real-time data. BAM is used to improve the speed and effectiveness of business operations by keeping track of what is happening and making issues visible quickly. It is a real-time, event-driven concept that is subtle but powerful. Enabling managers to compute high-level, complex event aggregates and thresholds to make better informed, strategic decisions.

In this session we will dive into the BAM concept and explore a way into BAM implementation inside Alfresco & Activiti, guided by a real life usecase.

speakers.summary:

title: Would the commercial open source software you depend on survive a zombie apocalypse?
targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
Earlier this year I wrote a blog post entitled, 'Would the commercial open source software you depend on survive a zombie apocalypse?' [1]. The post asks whether or not a piece of commercial open source software would survive if the commercial company behind it ceased to exist.

Zombies aren't real, of course, but companies fold, get acquired, or lose interest in their community. What is the risk of that happening to Alfresco Software, Inc., and what does it mean to our community?

In this session I will argue that mitigating this risk is the single most important reason for this organization to exist. I hope to convince you of that, and, in so doing, motivate you to contribute and perhaps bring focus to the organization's activities.

[1] http://ecmarchitect.com/archives/2016/01/04/4054

speakers.name: Jeff
speakers.summary: Jeff has made many contributions to the Alfresco community since he started working with Alfresco in 2005. Examples range from code, to tutorials and informative blog posts, to code camps, meetups, and conference sessions. In 2008, Jeff wrote the Alfresco Developer Guide, the first developer-focused book on Alfresco and in 2013, Jeff co-authored CMIS and Apache Chemistry in Action. Jeff was the Chief Community Officer at Alfresco until 2014. Jeff is the founder of Metaversant Group, a consulting firm focused on content management and search. He has spent nearly 20 years delivering ECM and search solutions to Fortune 500 and Global 1000 clients. In addition to frequent appearances at Alfresco events, Jeff has spoken at conferences such as JBoss World, KMWorld, ApacheCon, OSCON, JavaONE, and Devoxx.

title: Using Alfresco within the maintenance sector
targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
We'll be presenting a case study of a Electronic Engineering company who uses an ERP system to manage their work and we've:
- Integrated Alfresco with their ERP system
- Migrated their network drive
- Use of mobile devices to get data into Alfresco

In the future:
- Use Ephesoft to classify data
- Use mobile devices to fetch data directly from Alfresco

title: Alfresco SPK
targetAudience: Business Users, Newbies in Alfresco technologies, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
Alfresco SPK is a toolset that can be used by stack operators (Devops/Architects/Engineers, Support, QA, Sales, Marketing, ...) to define Alfresco immutable Images, testing them locally first, also for arbitrarily complex architectures.

It allows you to:

Run an arbitrarily complex stack locally
Build (immutable) image(s) with the exact same provisioning logic used for local run
Test immutable images locally
Run a stack on any orchestration tool with the same provisioning logic used for local runs

title: The Journey to Digital Renaissance
targetAudience: Everyone
abstract: Organizations around the world are facing new problems, increased complexity, and higher expectations of delivery and engagement. New technology often seems to be a part of the problem as much as it is the solution. By looking beyond the technology to find new ways of organizing our business, we can design a future that is more agile and adaptable and that still maintains the stability and resilience that we require to thrive in the long run. In this presentation, John will examine how digital technology will revolutionize the way we do business.

speakers.name: John
speakers.summary:
John Newton is the CTO and Founder of Alfresco Software.

In 1990, John co-founded, designed and led the development of Documentum®, acquired by EMC®. For the next ten years, he invented many of the concepts widely used in the industry today. In addition, he built Documentum's marketing and professional services organizations in Europe.

John has also been an Entrepreneur-in-Residence at Benchmark Capital. John was one of the founding engineers at Ingres® where he helped develop the world's first commercial relational database. John graduated with a BS in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from the University of California at Berkeley.

title: REST API of the future
targetAudience: Newbies in Alfresco technologies, System Administrators, Developers starting to work with Alfresco, Experienced Alfresco developers, Architects and Technical Managers
abstract:
Alfresco Repository comes with a great REST API but some of these API's can be difficult to navigate and use.

But Alfresco will show us about the future of REST API's, where the market is moving and how we are embracing this future at Alfresco.

Come and see how straightforward it will soon be to manage files, folders, custom node types, shared links and much more. The future is closer than you think !

He has helped to architect and develop Alfresco's cloud services. Most recently he has been working on extending and improving the Alfresco Platform APIs. Jan has a First-Class BSc / MEng (Hons) in Software Engineering from Imperial College.

abstract: The analytics in Alfresco represent an emerging interest for the users and the integration with Pentaho is the leading solution on both the Community and Enterprise Editions. AAAR is beyond the 4-th version and has bundled reports, dashboards and free analysis on audit data, repository and workflows. But in most cases, the bundled analytics should be customized to cover the business needs. In this talk is shown how to develop a customized set of analytics starting simply from some business questions. All of this to create your own Business Intelligence solution over one or more Alfresco instances.
